message.content: We refer to PubMed Health and other medical sources for help. The patient's T-score of -2.6 indicates osteoporosis, and among the options, only Raloxifene is used to treat osteoporosis and is known to cause hot flashes as a side effect. Alendronate and Zoledronic acid are also used for osteoporosis but do not cause hot flashes. Denosumab is used to treat osteoporosis but has not been known to cause hot flashes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s T-score indicates osteoporosis and among the options, Raloxifene is used to prevent osteoporosis. Hot flashes are a known side effect of Raloxifene. Alendronate, Denosumab, and Zoledronic acid are also used to prevent osteoporosis but are less likely to cause hot flashes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a T-score indicative of osteoporosis, and Raloxifene is a medication used to treat and prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. Hot flashes are a common side effect of taking Raloxifene. Alendronate and Zoledronic acid are also medications used to treat osteoporosis, but they do not cause hot flashes. Denosumab is used to treat osteoporosis as well, but it does not cause hot flashes either.

However, raloxifene is also used to treat hot flashes, which is the patient's current complaint. Therefore, raloxifene is the most likely medication that was prescribed.

Among the options, raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that can help prevent osteoporosis and also relieve hot flashes, a common symptom of menopause. Alendronate and zoledronic acid are bisphosphonates used to treat osteoporosis but do not relieve hot flashes. Denosumab is another option for osteoporosis but also does not relieve hot flashes.
